skill.name: backend-models
skill.description: Define and configure database models with proper naming, relationships, timestamps, data types, constraints, and validation. Use this skill when creating or editing model files in app/Models/, Eloquent model classes, model relationships (hasMany, belongsTo, etc.), database table structures, model attributes and casts, model factories, or seeders. Use when working on model validation logic, database constraints, foreign key relationships, indexes, scopes, accessors, mutators, or any ORM-related model configuration.
skill.summary: Define and configure database models with proper naming, relationships, timestamps, data types, constraints, and validation for Laravel Eloquent and similar ORM frameworks.
skill.author: DevanB

security_audit.summary: All 16 static findings are false positives. The skill is a pure documentation skill containing only markdown guidelines. The scanner incorrectly flagged metadata strings (URLs, hashes), documentation file paths, and markdown code formatting backticks as security threats. No executable code exists in this skill.

content.value_statement: Creating backend models requires careful attention to relationships, validation, and database constraints. This skill provides Claude with clear guidelines for defining Laravel Eloquent models that follow best practices.
actual_capabilities: Define Laravel Eloquent model classes with proper structure
Configure model relationships including hasMany, belongsTo, belongsToMany, hasOne, and morphTo
Set up model casts, fillable properties, and hidden attributes
Implement model validation rules and business logic constraints
Configure database timestamps, soft deletes, and model events
Create model scopes and accessor/mutator methods
limitations: This skill focuses on Laravel Eloquent patterns. Other ORM frameworks may require different conventions
The skill provides guidelines but does not execute database migrations or schema changes
Complex legacy database schemas may require manual overrides to the recommended patterns

use_cases.title: New Model Creation
use_cases.description: Create a new Eloquent model with proper relationships, casts, and validation for a Laravel application feature

use_cases.title: Model Refactoring
use_cases.description: Review and update existing model files to follow consistent naming, relationship definitions, and attribute handling

use_cases.title: Model Validation Setup
use_cases.description: Add validation rules, constraints, and business logic to models to ensure data integrity
use_cases.target_user: Backend engineers focused on data quality

prompt_templates.title: Basic Model Creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new Laravel Eloquent model called {ModelName} in app/Models/. Include proper table naming, primary key configuration, timestamps, and fillable attributes for {fields}.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating a simple model with basic structure

prompt_templates.title: Model with Relationships
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a {ModelName} model with a {relationshipType} relationship to the {RelatedModel} model. Configure the foreign key and any additional relationship options.

prompt_templates.title: Model with Validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Add validation rules to the {ModelName} model. Include required fields, data types, and any custom validation logic for {businessRules}.

prompt_templates.title: Complete Model with Scopes
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a comprehensive {ModelName} model including relationships, casts, accessors, mutators, local scopes, and boot method for model event handling.
prompt_templates.scenario: Building a full-featured model with advanced patterns

output_examples.input: Create a User model with relationships to Post and Comment models
output_examples.output: A complete User.php model file with hasMany relationships to Post and Comment, proper $fillable array, $casts configuration for dates, and relationship methods defined with correct foreign keys.

output_examples.input: Add validation to the Product model for price and inventory
output_examples.output: Updated Product model with validation rules on the $rules property, accessor methods for formatted price display, and mutator for ensuring positive values.

best_practices: Use plural table names and singular model names following Laravel conventions
Define explicit foreign keys in relationship methods for clarity
Keep models focused with separate concerns handled by services or repositories
anti_patterns: Avoid putting business logic directly in models; use dedicated service classes
Do not expose sensitive fields using $fillable; use $guarded or explicit fillable
Avoid magic numbers in relationships; always specify foreign keys explicitly

faq.question: What ORM frameworks does this skill support?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on Laravel Eloquent patterns. The concepts transfer to other PHP ORMs with similar conventions.

faq.question: Does this skill create database migrations?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides model-level guidance. Database schema changes require separate migration skills.

faq.question: Can this skill help with existing legacy models?
faq.answer: Yes, the guidelines help review and improve existing models, though legacy conventions may require manual overrides.

faq.question: What relationship types are supported?
faq.answer: hasMany, belongsTo, belongsToMany, hasOne, hasManyThrough, morphTo, morphMany, morphOne, and morphToMany.

faq.question: Does this skill handle model events and observers?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill provides guidance on configuring model boot methods and event handling patterns.

faq.question: Can this skill generate model factories?
faq.answer: The skill provides guidance on factory patterns but does not generate factory code directly.
